entry.title: Re: Business Context to Outgoing Checks (FIN_FO_PAYM_CHEC...
entry.content:
Dear @brunobrito2,

In Public Cloud this is expected behavior for Outgoing Checks:

  • The check output you reference (Form: FIN_FO_PAYM_CHECK_US, Data Source: FDP_FFO_PAYM_CHECK_SRV) is not released for key-user extensibility in the way other output forms are. In particular the underlying FDP data source is not available for extension, so you won’t get a Business Context for it in Custom Fields and Logic

SAP Community below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/payment-voucher-with-check-in-manage-outgoing-checks-s-4hc/qaq-p/12711199

  • SAP also documents for this check form that there is no extensibility logic / master form override available (example shown for address determination), which aligns with the absence of Custom Logic hooks for the form generation

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3654275

As a result you cannot add new custom fields (YY1*/ZZ*) to the Outgoing Check form data model via Custom Fields nor populate them via Custom Logic for this specific scenario

Supported/proposal options

Option A: Change the check layout but only with existing fields

You can adjust the form layout by creating your own template and assigning it in Output Management but you’re still limited to fields that already exist in the delivered data model

High-level steps:

  1. Maintain Form Templates  app download the delivered template adjust it externally, upload as a Z* template
  2. Output Parameter Determination app, show Rules for = Outgoing Check, Determination Step Form Template, assign your Z* template for output type CHECK

 

This is the standard way SAP positions outgoing-check form configuration

IMPORTANT: This does not enable adding new custom fields to the form payload

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/031c345485b84c8c94265be9ef61d3a8/ecdfbb2e23c24b53a74e03d1ecb07602.html

Option B: Put the extra information on a different, extensible output

If the business requirement is the recipient must see these extra fields the usual clean approach in Public Cloud is to output them on Payment Advice or a similar extensible payment document because SAP explicitly supports adding custom fields there

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/031c345485b84c8c94265be9ef61d3a8/50d73483ee7b4b2a9bf974113cf51ead.html

Option C: Use an existing standard field that already prints on the check (workaround)

If the requirement is strictly must appear on the check face, you usually have to map the value into a standard field that:

  • is already available in the check data source and
  • is already printed or can be printed on the form for example, reference / note / text fields that are part of the payment or line item context

This is a business workaround, but it is often the only in-system option when the check payload is not extensible

SAP Community below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/payment-voucher-with-check-in-manage-outgoing-checks-s-4hc/qaq-p/12711199

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP Functional Consultants (OTC, P2P, etc.) in the Era of AI Agents - Things might change...
entry.content:
Traditional Functional Testing in SAP

SAP Functional Consultants (in areas like Order-to-Cash (OTC) or Procure-to-Pay (P2P)) have historically focused on configuring business processes and validating them via SAP’s user interfaces (SAP GUI or Fiori apps). Testing of integrated business processes was largely manual and deterministic – for a given input and configuration, the expected output was known. Common practices included:

  • Manual Process Execution: Executing transactions step-by-step in SAP (e.g. creating a Sales Order or Purchase Order) and verifying the outcome on the UI.
  • Using Transaction WE19 for IDocs: If a process involved EDI messages or IDocs, consultants might use WE19 (IDoc test tool) to simulate inbound or outbound IDoc processing. This allowed testing of interfaces that start with an IDoc, but only for classic EDI scenarios.
  • Relying on Integration Teams: For more complex integrations (like web services or APIs), functional consultants often depended on technical teams or waited for external partners to send test messages. Without specialized tools, they had no easy way to simulate those external calls themselves. As a result, testing cycles could be slow and dependent on others. Functional consultants typically viewed advanced automation tools as out-of-scope or overly technical – treating them “like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work”. This mindset led to minimal adoption of test automation by functional teams, keeping many tests manual and time-consuming.

The Shift to Integrated and AI-Driven Processes

Today’s SAP landscapes are increasingly integrated and intelligent. Several trends are transforming how business processes run and, consequently, how they must be tested:

  • Proliferation of APIs and Services: Many business processes now involve web services, REST/OData APIs, and cloud integrations (SAP Integration Suite). For example, an order might be created via an e-commerce API call, or a procurement process might involve a cloud portal sending data into S/4HANA via OData. These are not easily simulated with old tools like WE19 (which only works for IDocs).
  • Event-Driven and Cross-System Flows: End-to-end processes span multiple systems (SAP and non-SAP). A single workflow (e.g. Order-to-Cash) might trigger events in warehouses, tax portals, banks, or partner systems. Testing such flows (using for example SAP Advanced Event Mesh technologies) means ensuring each interface and handoff works – something beyond the scope of a single SAP GUI transaction.
  • Introduction of SAP AI Agents (e.g. SAP Joule): SAP is embedding Agentic AI into its applications. Agents like SAP Joule can autonomously perform tasks when given a goal or input (for instance, reading an incoming email with a purchase order PDF and then creating a Sales Order, Delivery, and Invoice in S/4HANA without human clicks). Instead of a user navigating SAP screens, the AI agent orchestrates the process. This is powerful, but it changes the nature of testing: you may need to test the agent’s behavior and the end results, rather than a user interface.

These changes bring a major challenge: the “death of determinism” in testing. With static workflows, one could predict “Input X via transaction Y will produce output Z” every time. An AI-driven process, however, might not follow the exact same path each run – the agent could take different actions or sequence of steps to achieve the same goal, and in worst cases might even “hallucinate” successes. For example, the agent might respond, “Order created successfully!”

Figure 1 – Order created – assuming you trust me

with a polite confirmation, but due to a hidden error (like a mis-mapped field), the order was never actually saved in the database. Traditional test cases that expect a fixed outcome can miss such issues, creating a verification gap where the system’s UI or the agent’s message says everything is fine while the database tells another story. In short, just because the AI agent says it did something, doesn’t guarantee the SAP system state changed accordingly.

Why Traditional Testing Methods Fall Short

Given the above shifts, the old ways of testing have clear limitations:

  • Inability to Simulate New Triggers: Tools like WE19 work for IDoc-based interfaces, but many modern processes begin with different triggers (HTTP calls, cloud events, emails to AI agents). Without the ability to simulate these, functional consultants cannot fully test the process on their own. For example, you can’t use WE19 to simulate a REST API call or an incoming email – you’d need a tool or script to mimic those external inputs.
  • Manual UI Testing Doesn’t Cover Backend Integration: A consultant testing via SAP GUI might verify that if they manually create an order, the subsequent IDoc or output is correct. But what if the order is created by an AI agent or an external system call? You’d have to initiate that external trigger and then verify the outcome inside SAP. Manually, this is cumbersome – it might involve sending a request via an API client (like Postman) or waiting for the AI to act, then checking multiple SAP tables or transactions to ensure everything posted correctly. This goes beyond the traditional comfort zone of many functional testers.
  • Non-Deterministic AI Behavior: As mentioned, an AI agent may not behave exactly the same way each time. Traditional test scripts that expect step-by-step consistency may fail even though the end result is acceptable, or worse, may pass a conversational check while missing a functional failure. Most AI governance tools on the market (so-called “guardrail” platforms) focus on prompt safety, security, and compliance – ensuring the AI doesn’t produce toxic output or leak data. They usually do not validate functional integrity of what the AI did. In other words, they watch what the agent says or intends (the tool calls), but not what actually happened in SAP S/4HANA system. If an AI agent politely confirms an action that failed in the backend, a guardrail or conversation test won’t catch that. This is a huge blind spot for enterprise scenarios.

In summary, the combination of more complex integration points and AI-driven logic means traditional, manual testing by clicking through SAP or using limited tools is no longer sufficient. Organizations risk missing critical issues if they don’t adopt new testing approaches. The question is: how will the SAP functional consultant’s role evolve to address this?

Evolving Role of the Functional Consultant: From GUI Tester to End-to-End Process Validator/Guardian 

Moving forward, SAP functional consultants in OTC, P2P, and other domains will likely see their responsibilities broaden. They will still configure business processes, but they will also need to ensure those processes work across system boundaries and with AI in the loop. Key aspects of this evolution include:

  • Testing Beyond the SAP GUI: Consultants will spend less time on purely manual UI testing and more on end-to-end scenario testing. For an order process, this might mean triggering the process the same way it would happen in real life (e.g. via an incoming EDI message, an API call, or an AI agent prompt) and then verifying the results across the system. The focus shifts from “Did the screen show the right data?” to “Did the entire workflow execute correctly in the backend systems?”.
  • Becoming API & Integration Savvy: While they may not become full developers, functional consultants will need a working understanding of how to simulate or call APIs, web services, and other integration points. For instance, a P2P consultant might use a tool to send a test JSON payload to an OData service that creates a vendor invoice, then check if the invoice posted and the approval workflow started. In essence, they take on some duties of an API tester, validating that the service calls and data mappings yield the expected results in SAP. This skillset ensures that even if a process is initiated outside of SAP, the consultant can still test it end-to-end.
  • Validating AI Agent Outcomes: As AI agents (like SAP Joule) handle tasks that consultants used to do via the UI, consultants will act as quality guardians for these agents. They might orchestrate test “conversations” or inputs for the agent and then verify the outcomes. For example, an OTC consultant may provide a test email (with an order PDF) to the SAP Joule agent and then confirm that: a Sales Order was created with correct data, a Delivery was generated, and an Invoice posted – all according to the business rules. Rather than checking a UI, they’ll check SAP backend records, document flow, or even database entries to ensure the agent’s actions are functionally correct. In other words, the consultant becomes a "human in the loop" for AI validation, focusing on what the AI did in the system rather than what the AI said.
  • Defining Success Criteria for Probabilistic Processes: In deterministic testing, success is binary (the output matches expected or not). With AI and complex integrations, success may need to be defined in terms of acceptable outcomes or system states. Functional consultants will be instrumental in defining test case expectations for AI-driven processes: e.g., “An order should be created with the correct customer and items, the tax should be calculated as per configuration, and no error IDocs should result.” They will design test cases that verify these conditions, even if the exact path the AI agent took (which transactions, what sequence) is not pre-scripted. This is sometimes referred to as a Functional Workflow Execution (FWE) validation – ensuring the workflow’s end results meet functional requirements, regardless of how the agent executed it.
  • Collaboration with Technical Teams: As their role expands into what was traditionally technical testing, functional consultants will likely work more closely with integration experts, BASIS, and QA automation engineers. They’ll need to understand logs, interface monitors, and possibly AI logs to troubleshoot when a test fails. However, rather than waiting for those teams to do the tests, the consultant will be empowered to run many tests themselves, escalating to experts only when something truly goes wrong at a technical level. This collaboration ensures that business process knowledge (which the functional consultant has) is combined with technical validation – a necessity for complex scenarios.

In essence, functional consultants are becoming end-to-end business process testers, ensuring that “if X leaves SAP or comes into SAP, it is exactly what the outside world expects,” even when X is triggered by an AI or external system. They will adopt some of the mindset and tools of AI testers and API testers, but with a focus on business correctness and usability rather than pure technical details.

The Role of Specialized Testing Tools (Int4 Suite and Similar)

Crucially, this evolution doesn’t mean every functional consultant must learn programming or become an automation engineer. New smart testing tools are emerging to bridge the gap, allowing functional consultants to test complex scenarios with minimal coding. One example is Int4 Suite, which has been highlighted as an “enterprise AI validator” or “secret shopper” for SAP processes. Tools like Int4 Suite offer features that directly address the needs we discussed:

  • Simulation of External Systems (Service Virtualization): Int4 Suite provides simulation agents that can stand in for external partners or systems during testing. For instance, a consultant can simulate an EDI partner sending an ORDERS message or a third-party warehouse sending a confirmation, without waiting for the real system. The tool leverages real production data – consultants can select actual historical messages (IDocs, API payloads, etc.) and replay them in the test environment on-demand. This means even if a process normally begins outside SAP, the functional tester can trigger it at will. It works for both EDI/IDoc and non-EDI (API/web service) interactions.
  • Simple Interface, No Coding Required: Instead of forcing consultants to write scripts or learn complex test frameworks, the tool presents a user-friendly interface (e.g., pick a historical message, tweak some values, and send). As one source put it, “The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment”. This approach avoids a steep learning curve. Consultants can use their SAP process knowledge to choose relevant test cases, and the tool handles the technical message sending and data injection behind the scenes.
  • End-to-End Validation (Deep Backend Checks): A critical feature is automatic result validation. When the consultant triggers a test (whether it’s creating a doc in SAP or sending an inbound message), Int4 Suite will automatically check the outcomes at a granular level. For example, after an outbound IDoc is generated or an API call is processed, the tool compares the new output to the expected output (often using the historical production message as the “gold standard”). It can validate that every relevant field matches, that totals are correctly calculated, and even that follow-on documents (like an invoice or accounting document) are created as expected. This is exactly the kind of functional integrity check that would catch an AI agent’s mistakes – if the agent missed a field mapping or made an error, the discrepancy would be flagged when comparing the new system output to the known correct output from a similar past scenario.

 Figure 2 – Backend Validation in Int4 Suite

 

  • “Secret Shopper” Testing for AI Agents: In the context of SAP’s AI agents, a tool like this can act as a secret shopper – essentially a fake customer that tests the agent. For the earlier example of an email-to-order scenario, Int4 Suite can automatically retrieve a real email and PDF order from the company’s archive, modify certain details to make it a unique test, and send it to the AI agent. Once the AI agent processes it (creating an order, delivery, invoice), Int4 Suite dives into S/4HANA’s backend to verify each document’s presence and correctness (e.g., checking that net value, tax, shipping point, etc., match the expected outcome). This way, the agent’s entire end-to-end functionality is validated, not just the message it returned in the chat. If something failed (like the agent said “order created” but no order exists, or the invoice values are wrong), the tool will catch it immediately.

 

Figure 3 – secret shopper figure

  • Use of Historical Data and Dynamic Data Fabrication: Because these tools often integrate with SAP directly, they can pull realistic test data. Int4 Suite’s approach is to use a “robotic crawler” to fetch historical messages and then dynamically fabricate variants of them for testing. This ensures test scenarios are very close to real business cases (with all the complexity of real data), increasing the chance of catching issues. Consultants can test edge cases (like a huge Black Friday order load, or a partially delivered order response) by simply replaying those real scenarios in a controlled way. This capability is far more powerful than hand-crafting test data in a spreadsheet.

By equipping functional consultants with such simulation and validation agents, organizations get several benefits: “Test cycles shorten dramatically, reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops, and confidence in end-to-end quality rises.” In other words, a tool like Int4 Suite transforms the functional consultant into a self-sufficient end-to-end tester, without turning them into programmers. They can rapidly run through many integrated scenarios on their own, as frequently as needed, which is essential in an AI-driven, non-deterministic world. It fills in the missing piece of testing by confirming that what leaves or enters SAP in these integrated processes is correct to the last field.

Possible Adaptation Strategies for Consultants

The transition to this new reality won’t happen overnight for everyone. Different organizations and individuals might take different approaches as these changes loom:

  • Full Embrace of the New Role: Many functional consultants (or entire teams) will fully embrace the role of AI/API-enabled process testers. They will upskill on using tools like Int4 Suite or other SAP testing frameworks and become comfortable simulating APIs and AI-driven scenarios. In this mode, a consultant effectively becomes a hybrid of a functional expert and an integration tester. They design test cases, use simulation tools to execute them, and interpret the results. This path ensures they remain highly relevant and valuable, as they can guarantee that business processes work correctly across all layers. It does require learning new tools and thinking beyond just SAP’s UI, but the payoff is a much faster and more reliable testing cycle – and fewer production surprises. (This is the “yes in all of those” changes scenario – taking on AI testing, API testing, and new tools altogether.)
  • Remain SAP-Centric (Traditionalist Approach): Some may choose (or initially attempt) to stick narrowly to classic SAP customization and UI testing, leaving the AI and integration aspects to specialized testers or developers. For instance, a consultant might test only the SAP transaction portions and assume that the integration team will ensure external inputs/outputs are correct. This “just SAP” approach might feel comfortable, but it has risks. It can create bottlenecks (always waiting on someone else for the end-to-end test) and blind spots (the consultant might miss how a configuration change impacts the API or agent behavior). In the long run, as SAP agents and integrations become core to processes, a consultant who doesn’t engage with those aspects could find their testing incomplete or their role limited. This option might work in the short term in organizations where roles are strictly separated, but it’s likely not sustainable as the norm shifts toward cross-functional testing skills.
  • Partial or Gradual Adoption: A middle path is to incrementally adopt these new responsibilities. Consultants might start by learning to use one simulation tool for a specific pain point (say, simulating an EDI partner message) while still doing other tests manually. Or they might pair up with integration engineers for a while – the consultant defines the business scenarios and expected results, and the engineer helps set up the API calls or agent triggers. Over time, the consultant picks up more of the skills and tools. In this “yes, but not too much” scenario, they do expand their role, but carefully and not all at once. This can be practical for teams that need to maintain current projects while gradually modernizing their testing approach. The key is that even partial adoption of tools like Int4 Suite can yield significant improvements (for example, using it just to simulate inbound messages can save a lot of time). Eventually, as confidence and competence grow, consultants can take on more.
  • New Specialist Roles Emerge: It’s also possible that entirely new roles or job titles will appear – for example, “SAP AI Process Tester” or “Enterprise AI Validation Engineer.” These could be professionals who bridge the gap between functional knowledge and AI technical know-how. Experienced functional consultants might transition into such roles, or they might work alongside them. In either case, the existence of such roles underlines that testing integrated, AI-infused processes is a specialty of its own. Consultants should be prepared to collaborate with these specialists or become one themselves. What’s likely, however, is that even if dedicated AI testers exist, the functional consultant will still need to closely cooperate and provide business context – so some level of understanding of the new testing paradigms is necessary.

Regardless of the approach, one thing is clear: the need for robust testing of end-to-end processes (including AI actions) is only going to increase. SAP functional consultants are in a prime position to take up that challenge, given their deep understanding of business rules and process outcomes. They will not necessarily code test scripts from scratch, but they will orchestrate and validate tests using new-generation tools. As the enterprise software world embraces “probabilistic” AI agents and highly API-driven architectures, the consultant’s role evolves from simply configuring and eyeballing the result on a screen, to actively safeguarding the integrity of complex, automated workflows.

Preparing for the Future

For SAP functional consultants wondering how to stay ahead in this changing landscape, here are a few final thoughts:

  • Get Familiar with Integration Technologies: You don’t need to be a developer, but learn the basics of how data enters/exits SAP in your domain (OData services, IDoc flows, BAPIs, etc.). Understand the tools available (e.g., SAP API Hub, Int4 Suite, or SAP’s own testing utilities) to send or monitor those interfaces.
  • Experiment with AI (in a Safe Environment): If your organization is introducing SAP AI agents like Joule, try to get involved in the early testing. Ask to be part of the pilot. Treat it as an opportunity to build “AI literacy” – learn how the agent is supposed to operate, what data it uses, and how to trigger it. Maybe set up a sandbox where you can play with the agent’s skills without risk.
  • Leverage Test Automation Tools Designed for SAP: Tools such as Int4 Suite (and others in the SAP ecosystem) are there to help. They are built with SAP processes in mind (understanding IDocs, BAPIs, document flows) which generic testing tools might not easily handle. Investing time to learn one of these tools can pay off greatly. As we saw, providing simulation agents to consultants can change the game by eliminating dependencies and speeding up tests. It’s worth advocating within your project to bring in such tools – not just for AI, but for any integrated process testing.
  • Mindset Shift – From Tester to Guardian of the Process: Finally, embrace a mindset change. Instead of seeing testing as a step where you click through a script to confirm your configuration works, view yourself as the guardian of the end-to-end process. Your goal is to ensure that when all the moving parts (SAP modules, integrations, AI agents, partner systems) play together, the business outcome is correct and reliable. This holistic view will naturally drive you to adopt whatever techniques and tools are needed (be it learning to read a JSON payload or interpreting an AI agent log). It’s an exciting expansion of the functional consultant’s role – one that can make you even more valuable in an AI-powered enterprise.

Conclusion

Yes, SAP functional consultants will evolve to become more like AI/API testers for their business processes – in fact, they will become full-spectrum process validators. They’ll still use their core business knowledge, but augmented with new testing skills and tools. The introduction of AI agents and heavily integrated processes doesn’t diminish the importance of the functional consultant; on the contrary, it amplifies the need for their insight to ensure these intelligent systems do the right thing. The likely scenario (and in many cases, the only viable one) is that consultants embrace this change: using specialized tools, they will test conversations and API calls with the same comfort as they tested transactions in SAPGUI. This comprehensive approach is what will maintain enterprise-grade trust in an era where software is no longer fully deterministic. By adopting solutions that allow deep backend verification and service virtualization, functional consultants can close the “verification gap” and keep their processes running smoothly.

Further Learning on Int4 Suite 

  • SAP Learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

entry.title: Re: SAC Data Action rounding differences - how to force 2...
entry.content:
Hi @vinay_009 

There is "ROUND()" function in the Advanced formulas script. You can get your expected result from the script logic with ROUND() function.

In your case, if Price & Quantity and to get the Revenue (Price * Quantity)

  • Price: 132.7628388
  • Quantity: 1,500

 

Without Rounding

  • Calculate Result

  • Advanced Formulas script
DATA([d/Account] = "Revenue") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Price") * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Quantity")

 

With Rounding

  • Calculate Result

  • Advanced Formulas script
DATA([d/Account] = "Revenue") = ROUND(RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Price"), 2) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Quantity")

 I hope this is helpful to you, and if I have misunderstood anything, please feel free to reach out.

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: Unable to Delete Tax Code Rate Due to Posted Documents
entry.content:
Yes — the recommendation still applies even though the changes were made only in your Test system and not yet transported to Production.

Here’s why:

System behavior is the same across environments: The restriction on deleting tax rates once documents exist after the valid‑from date is a standard control in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. It applies equally in Test, Quality, and Production.

Audit integrity principle: SAP prevents deletion because the tax rate has already been “in use” in posted documents. Reversals don’t change that fact. This rule is not environment‑specific.

Transport impact: Since you haven’t transported the 6% rate to Production yet, you can simply avoid transporting that change. In Production, you can directly maintain the correct validity interval (e.g., keep 6.72% until 19.01.2026, then 6% from 20.01.2026 if that’s correct). If the TR is not yet released, you can carry out the changes in the same TR

entry.title: Re: How to capture the message content in a Exception sub...
entry.content:
I had the same problem... It's a Namespace Problem...

I assume, you've already found a solution or a workaround. But here my solution for anyone searching:

instead of //error/message use //*[local-name()='error']/*[local-name()='message'] as an xpath-expression according to note 3424544

my XML:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<error xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices/metadata">
	<code>/IWBEP/CM_MGW_RT/022</code>
	<message xml:lang="de">some error occured</message>
	<innererror>
		<application>
			<component_id/>
			<service_namespace>/SAP/</service_namespace>
			<service_id>ZZ_ODATA_SRV</service_id>
			<service_version>0001</service_version>
		</application>
		<transactionid>1a9947e4157a42dfb7c46670b7aa999e</transactionid>
		<timestamp>20260122085637.0575830</timestamp>
		<Error_Resolution>
			<SAP_Transaction>For backend administrators: use ADT feed reader "SAP Gateway Error Log" or run transaction /IWFND/ERROR_LOG on SAP Gateway hub system and search for entries with the timestamp above for more details</SAP_Transaction>
			<SAP_Note>See SAP Note 1797736 for error analysis (https://service.sap.com/sap/support/notes/1797736)</SAP_Note>
		</Error_Resolution>
		<errordetails>
			<errordetail>
				<ContentID/>
				<code>/IWBEP/CX_MGW_BUSI_EXCEPTION</code>
				<message>some error occured</message>
				<propertyref/>
				<severity>error</severity>
				<target/>
				<transition>false</transition>
			</errordetail>
		</errordetails>
	</innererror>
</error>

entry.title: LGM Knowledge Snippet: The idea behind Normalized Quantities
entry.content:
How do you compare 100 pieces of Product A with 50 boxes of Product B? How do you know when you've consolidated enough cargo to fill a truck? This is where Normalized Quantities come into play in SAP Logistics Management - a concept designed to represent estimated pallet footprints for meaningful consolidation decisions.

The Pallet Footprint Problem

In transportation planning, the key question is: "How much truck space does this cargo need?" The answer isn't in pieces, boxes, or kilograms - it's in how many pallet positions the cargo occupies on the truck floor.

Think about it: A truck driver doesn't care if you have 1,000 units or 10,000 units. They care about: "How many pallet spots does this take up on my truck?"

That's exactly what normalized quantities represent in LGM: the pallet footprint of your cargo.

The Geographic Challenge: Not All Pallets Are Equal

Here's where it gets interesting. When we say "pallet footprint," which pallet are we talking about?

Euro-Pallet vs. US Pallet: A Real World Problem

In Europe, one of the most common standard for pallets is the Euro-pallet:

  • Dimensions: 1200mm × 800mm (0.96 m²)
  • Standard truck capacity: 33 pallets (of course, stringly depends on the equipment)
  • used Unit of Measure Code: EPA (for the example here, this is not a delivered content)

In the United States, it's the US pallet:

  • Dimensions: 48" × 40" (1.24m² - significantly larger footprint and depending on the heights volume)
  • Standard 53-foot trailer: 26-28 US pallet positions
  • used Unit of Measure Code: UPA (for the example here, this is not a delivered content)

Let's say you're shipping 1,200 units of Product X from two different warehouses:

Frankfurt Warehouse:
  • Product X: 120 units fit on 1 Euro-pallet
  • Normalized quantity: 1,200 ÷ 120 = 10 EPA
Chicago Warehouse:
  • Chicago Warehouse:
    Product X: 156 units per US pallet ( of course, this can also depend on the typical stack heights)
    Normalized quantity: 1,200 ÷ 156 = 7.7 UPA

Same product, same quantity, but very different number of pallet footprint used. This is why normalized quantities must be geography-specific - they represent actual physical footprint on region-specific trucks.

The key insight: Normalized quantities represent the regional standard pallet format for estimating truck/container capacity.

How SAP Logistics Management Implements This

Step 1: Determine the Regional Pallet Standard

When a Transportation Request is created, a business rule(NORMALIZED_UNIT_OF_MEASURE_DETERMINATION) determines which pallet format represents capacity for that geography:

IF Shipping Point DE01 → Normalized UoM = 'EPA' (Euro-pallet positions) IFShipping Point US02  → Normalized UoM = 'UPA' (US pallet positions) 

Step 2: Convert Everything to Pallet Equivalents

The system converts each item to pallet positions using product-specific conversion factors:

  • "200 pieces of Product A = 1 EPA position"
  • "4 cartons of Product B = 1 EPA position"
  • "2 boxes of Product C = 0.5 EPA position"

Step 3: Aggregate for Truck Capacity Decisions

All items are summed to show total pallet positions needed:

  • Transportation Request level: Sum of all item pallet positions
  • Consignment level: Sum of all assigned Transportation Requests

This aggregated number directly answers: "How many pallet positions do I need on the truck?"

On a note: At the moment we only do this aggregation if the normalized quantity can be determined for all items. This might become configurable in future.

Practical Example: Hamburg Distribution Center

You're consolidating LTL shipments from Hamburg. Your consolidation rule: "Ship when you reach 15 EPA pallet positions OR 12:00 noon, whichever comes first."

Throughout the morning, different products arrive:

Time Product Original Quantity Pallet Positions
9:00 AMIndustrial components480 pieces2.4 EPA
9:30 AMPackaged goods12 cartons3.0 EPA
10:15 AMBulk items84 boxes4.2 EPA
11:00 AMPre-palletized goods6 Euro-pallets6.0 EPA

Total: 15.6 EPA pallet positions ✅

The system triggers consolidation cutoff. You know exactly what you need: a truck with ~16 pallet positions, which is perfect for a standard European LTL carrier (they typically quote 15-20 pallet bands).

Behind the scenes, you're shipping "480 pieces + 12 cartons + 84 boxes + 6 pallets" - a complex mental calculation. But normalized to pallet positions, it's clear: 15.6 EPA pallet spots.

Why This Matters

The normalized quantity concept solves several critical problems:

  1. Consolidation Decisions: "Do I have enough cargo?" translates to "Do I have enough pallet positions?"This helps e.g. to determine the correct processing variant ( the respective input parameter is planned to be added for the processing variant determination)
  2. Carrier Determination: The best carrier can depend on the number of pallets you expect to ship.
  3. Carrier Communication: German carriers expect "15 EPA pallet positions." US carriers expect "5 UPA pallet positions." The system speaks their language.

Limitations

So far, the calculation is purely based on the determined UoM for the pallet equivalent, we do not consider e.g. history of realistic pallets used for a product and stackability, however this basic setup can already help for straight forward scenarios to come to better decisions and improve the visibility. of the expected transport demand.

Closing Thoughts

Normalized quantities translate the complex world of mixed products, different units of measure, and varied packaging into one simple question: "How many pallet positions does this cargo occupy?"

By using region-specific pallet standards (EPA in Frankfurt, UPA in Chicago, AUS in Sydney), LGM ensures that consolidation decisions reflect actual truck capacity requirements in each market.

The next time you see "15.6 EPA" on a consignment, remember: that's not just a number - it's telling you that you need 15-16 Euro-pallet positions on a European truck. It's the difference between guessing truck capacity and knowing exactly what you need.

And if you're wondering why 1,200 units converts to 10 pallets in Europe but only 4.3 pallets in the US? Now you know - a US pallet has literally double the footprint of a Euro-pallet, so fewer are needed to represent the same cargo.

Feel free to leave comments if you have questions about how normalized quantities work in your specific scenarios!

entry.title: Connecting IAS with Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) (Part 3)
entry.content:
In Part 1, the role of SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication (IAS) as the central identity layer for Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) was introduced.
In Part 2, an IAS tenant was created and made accessible on SAP BTP.

This article completes the setup by connecting the IAS tenant to DIV, explaining how authentication and authorization are enforced, and showing how administrators and end users are granted access to DIV provisioning and wallet tenants.

 

Authentication and Authorization Overview

Once IAS is connected to DIV, all access to DIV components is mediated by IAS. This applies to both:

  • DIV Provisioning UI (administrative access)
  • DIV Wallet Tenants (end-user access)

During authentication, IAS performs two checks:

  1. Authentication by verifying the user’s identity via the federated corporate identity provider
  2. Authorization by validating whether the authenticated user is allowed to access the requested DIV tenant or application

Only if both checks succeed access is granted.

This model ensures that authentication and authorization decisions are consistently enforced across the DIV components.

 

Step 1: Starting DIV Provisioning via SAP for Me

The connection between DIV and IAS is established during the DIV provisioning process in SAP for Me.

In SAP for Me, navigate to Systems & Provisioning → Provisioning

The Provisioning tab lists all systems that can be provisioned for the account. In the section “Systems to be Provisioned”, a Start Provisioning button is available (Figure 1).

Selecting this option initiates the provisioning workflow for DIV.

Figure 1: SAP for Me - Systems & Provisioning - Provisioning

 

During the provisioning process for DIV, an IAS tenant must be selected. The provisioning screen displays the available SAP Cloud Identity Services tenants. This might be the URL created during the previous blog article.

Typically, the default IAS tenant associated with the BTP global account is selected (Figure 2). Once confirmed, the provisioning request can be submitted. After a short processing time, the provisioning status changes from requested to provided. The DIV Provisioning Service becomes available and is automatically linked to the selected IAS tenant.

Figure 2: SAP for Me - Start New Provisioning Request

 

Step 2: IAS Application Created for DIV

As part of the provisioning process, an IAS application representing the DIV service is automatically created and linked to the corresponding BTP subaccount. This application functions as the technical anchor point for all authentication and authorization decisions related to DIV.

In the IAS Admin Console, this application appears under Applications & Resources, grouped under the relevant BTP subaccount (Figure 3).

Figure 3: DIV application automatically created in the IAS Admin Console and linked to the corresponding SAP BTP subaccount.

 

Step 3: Restricting Application Access in IAS

By default, IAS applications can be configured with different access modes. For enterprise DIV deployments, access must be restricted.

In the IAS Admin Console:

  1. Open the DIV application (Figure 4)
  2. Navigate to the Authentication and Access tab
  3. Select Private access mode

The Private option ensures that:

  • Users cannot self-register
  • Only users explicitly imported or provisioned are allowed to authenticate

This setting is mandatory for controlled, enterprise-grade DIV deployments.

Figure 4: Configuration of application access mode for the DIV application in IAS

 

Step 4: Authorization Model for DIV

IAS enforces authorization separately for:

  • DIV Provisioning UI
  • DIV Wallet Tenants

This separation enables fine-grained access control and clear separation of duties.

 

DIV Provisioning Authorization

The following user groups are created in the IAS tenant by default:

  • DIV_Provisioning_Admin

  • DIV_Provisioning_Viewer

Only users assigned to these groups are able to access provisioning functions such as tenant creation, configuration, and user management.

 

DIV Wallet Authorization

For wallet access, IAS restricts users to specific wallet tenants. Even if authentication succeeds, access is denied if the user is not authorized for the requested tenant.

This prevents lateral access between departments or partner organizations in multi-tenant environments.

 

Step 5: Importing Users and Assigning Roles in IAS

Users must be explicitly imported into IAS and assigned to the appropriate DIV-related groups.

In the IAS Admin Console:

  1. Navigate to Users & Authorizations
  2. Select the DIV application
  3. Choose Import Users and upload a CSV file (Figure 5)

The CSV file contains user attributes such as:

  • Login name
  • Email address
  • Status
  • Group memberships

An example CSV file includes a groups column containing DIV-specific roles (Figure 6). These group assignments determine whether a user receives provisioning access, wallet access, or both.

Figure 5: User and authorization management for the DIV application in the IAS Admin Console, including user import via CSV

 

Figure 6: Example CSV file used to import users into IAS with assigned DIV-specific authorization groups

 

Step 6: Authentication and Access Enforcement

When a user attempts to access a DIV component, IAS performs an authorization check.

For example, when accessing the DIV Provisioning UI, the user is first redirected to IAS. The authentication screen displays the associated BTP subaccount and requests credentials (Figure 7).

Figure 7: IAS authentication and authorization check triggered when accessing the DIV Provisioning UI

 

Only if:

  • Authentication via the corporate identity provider succeeds, and
  • The user belongs to a group authorized for the requested application,

is access granted and the user redirected back to DIV.

 

Resulting Architecture and Security Model

After completing the steps described above, the following architecture and security characteristics are in place:

  • IAS acts as the single authentication entry point for all DIV components
  • Corporate identity providers remain the source of user identities
  • Authorization is centrally enforced through IAS groups and role assignments
  • Administrative and end-user access paths are clearly separated at the application level
  • Multi-tenant isolation is consistently enforced

The trust relationship between the SAP BTP subaccount and IAS is established during provisioning and configuration. At runtime, IAS issues authentication tokens containing group claims. These tokens are validated directly by the DIV applications based on the preconfigured trust.

The result is a secure, scalable, and enterprise-ready DIV setup aligned with real-world organizational structures (Figure 8).

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Figure 8: High-level authentication and authorization flow for DIV using IAS

 

💡This concludes the three-part series on integrating SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication with Decentralized Identity Verification.

 

Read more

⬅️   Go back to Creating and Accessing an IAS Tenant on SAP BTP (Part 2)

⬅️⬅️   Go back to Why IAS Is Essential for Enterprise DIV Implementations (Part 1)

 

  • Introduction to SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) and Related SSI Blog Posts 
  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Data Spaces 
  • Feature Scope Description for Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV help page)
  • What Are Cloud Identity Services? (IAS help page)
  • Import or Update Users for a Specific Application (IAS help page)

entry.title: Introducing Partial Accept in Solution Quotation: A More Flexible Way to Fulfill Customer Outcomes
entry.content:
In today’s outcome‑driven business environment, customers expect solutions not just individual products or services. To support this shift, the Manage Solution Quotation application in On‑Premise and Private Cloud environments enables sales teams to combine multiple item categories into a single, comprehensive solution proposal. This unified quotation allows businesses to sell a complete outcome rather than a set of standalone offerings

When a solution quotation is fully accepted, the system automatically generates the appropriate follow‑up documents for each item category. For example:

  • All Sales Items transfer into a Sales Order
  • Service-related items generate the corresponding Service Orders or Service Contracts
  • Subscription elements create Subscription Contracts

While this automation simplifies downstream processes, it presents a challenge for businesses selling long‑term or phased outcomes. If the full solution is accepted at once, the system creates follow-up documents for the entire item and quantity set. Many customers, however, need the flexibility to fulfill outcomes gradually especially in multi‑phase projects or long-running service engagements.

Available from 2025 FPS0, Partial Accept feature enhances the flexibility and practicality of solution quotations., This enhancement allows customers to:

  • Accept only selected item/s or
  • Accept only a portion of the target quantity of specific items

Each partial acceptance triggers the creation of follow‑up documents only for the accepted scope, leaving the remaining items or quantities available for future acceptance.

Why Partial Accept Matters

The Partial Accept feature empowers businesses to:

  • Support Long-Term or Multi-Stage Solutions: Customers can use a single solution quotation over an extended period, accepting portions as needed.
  •  Manage Delivery and Fulfillment Flexibly: Instead of generating all follow-up documents at once, businesses can create them in stages aligned with their operational or customer timelines.
  •  Improve Outcome-Based Selling: When selling outcomes rather than discrete products, staged acceptance aligns better with real-world project progress.

Here is an Illustration how to use partial accept

Prerequisite Customising To use this feature set the Multiple References field to Yes under Customizing , Service->Transactions->Basic Settings->Define Item Categories for all relevant item categories.

Now you can use, first create solution quotation, including relevant target quantities of items, here you see new disabled button "Partially Accept" and new column "Released Quantity"

Once you saved and released all items, same like 'Accept' button, 'Partial Accept' button will also be enabled 

On clicking the Partial Accept button, a dialog window opens where the user can select the items and the required quantities they want to partially accept.

For example, based on your business requirements, you may choose to select only Sales Items, Spare Parts, and Service Items. Instead of accepting the full quantity (10), you can partially accept a target quantity of 2 for the selected items.

 
This Partial Accept will create respective follow-up documents Sales Order and Service  with 2 quantity of selected items

Now, using this flexibility, you are requested to create a sales order for line item 60 (a different sales item compared to item 10). Click the Partial Accept button again. In the same dialog window, you will notice that the target quantities of the previously accepted items have been reduced.

Next, select line item 60 and specify a partial quantity of 2 units. This action will create a new sales order (4743), rather than adding the item to the previously created sales order (4742).

in Transaction History you can see new sales order created, navigate and see the created sales order.

Again, as per your business requirement, you want to create a sales order with a few more quantities, this time, 1 unit of the sales item and a service order with 1 unit of the service item. Previously, we entered 2 units, leaving 8 units remaining. Now, we are going to enter 1 unit for both items, as shown in the image below.

On Accept it will create new sales order and service order document with respective items with 1 unit of quantity.

Similarly, the same approach can be applied to other items by leveraging Solution Quotation not only for selling bundles, but also for effectively managing solution items and their fulfillment with greater flexibility. By adopting the partial acceptance capability in your solution business, organizations can enable more controlled decision-making, phased commitments, and improved delivery outcomes.

I welcome your suggestions and feedback on this blog. If you have additional requirements or enhancement ideas, please submit them through the Customer Influence Portal.

entry.title: Re: Activity Allocation to revenue generating WBS-element...
entry.content:
Hello,

if you want to use a service cost rate that depends on the service cost level, it is important to enter the personnel number. Otherwise the service cost level cannot be derived. Either you have to use CATS or you have to manually enter the personnel number in the app "Manage Direct Activity Allocation".

W/o the personnel number, the system will not determine the service cost rate and will use the plan cost rate as a fallback.

Hope this helps to solve your issue.
Best regards,

Birgit

entry.title: Re: entries of 2l and ol ledger difference

entry.title: Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.  

SAP Cloud ERP is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem–customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I’d like to outline the innovations for SAP Cloud ERP 2602 in the area of Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management. These are the topics that are covered:

  • Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP (6JN) 
  • Project staffing view for resource managers (6JO) 
  • Allowing contingent workers (cost center procured) to record time on enterprise projects (1NT, 1Q4) 
  • Automatic removal of billing block for sales order billing plans (1NT) 
  • Joule as project assistant (beta), planned to be available mid-March
  • Further innovations

 

Check out my video to get a glimpse of the new features:

 

In today's fast-paced business environment, running projects efficiently, on time, and on budget is more critical than ever. This release is packed with features designed to bring more intelligence, automation, and transparency to your projects, ultimately driving significant business value. We’ve focused on streamlining processes, enhancing integration, and even giving you a glimpse into the future with AI-powered assistance.

Let's dive into the highlights that will help you unlock new levels of project success.

 

Enhancements in SAP Project and Resource Management

 

Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP

In complex projects spanning engineering, manufacturing, and services, a major challenge is keeping project execution plans in sync with core financial and logistical data. A delay in a design phase, for example, has a direct impact on procurement timelines and billing dates. If this information isn't shared instantly between the project planning tool and the core ERP, decisions are made based on outdated information. To solve this, our 2602 release supercharges the integration between SAP Project and Resource Management, our solution on the SAP Business Technology Platform, and SAP Cloud ERP. Now, when a project manager adjusts a project plan – such as extending a phase – the system automatically synchronizes these date changes with the core ERP in real time.

This direct synchronization ensures that your financial, commercial, and logistical data within SAP Cloud ERP always reflects the most current project reality, empowering you to make reliable decisions based on a single source of truth. By automating the update process, you eliminate the need for project teams to manually replicate date changes across systems, which significantly reduces administrative effort and minimizes the risk of human error. This tight integration also lays the groundwork for faster billing cycles, as milestone completions in the project plan can now directly trigger commercial processes in the core system.

 

Figure 1: Improved integration of project plan information between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management, enables better decision-making in projects through reliable, up-to-date project plan information.

 

Project staffing view for resource managers

Resource managers are constantly juggling demands from multiple projects, and gaining a clear, consolidated overview of the staffing situation for a specific project can be a fragmented and time-consuming process. To address this pain point, we are introducing a brand-new SAP Fiori app called “Manage Request Assignments”. This powerful application is designed specifically for resource managers, providing a single, project-centric view of all resource requests. It shows at a glance which roles have been fully staffed, which are partially staffed, and which are still open, eliminating the need to dig through multiple screens and reports.

This new application provides resource managers with unprecedented transparency into the staffing health of any project, allowing them to instantly identify bottlenecks and open demands without extensive research. Having all the necessary information in one place, with direct navigation to take action, streamlines the workflow and dramatically reduces the time it takes to staff open requests and get the right people on the right tasks. Ultimately, a clear, holistic overview empowers resource managers to more effectively optimize staffing within a single project or re-allocate experts across multiple projects, ensuring your most valuable resources are deployed with maximum impact.

 

Figure 2: The “Manage Request Assignments” application allows users to efficiently view the resource request and assignment details at a project level.

 

Other Innovations in SAP Project and Resource Management

Additional enhancements introduced in SAP Project and Resource Management. For example:

  • Technical user flow coverage (client credential flow) for some APIs
  • Use of actual dates in scheduling
  • Consideration of working and none working days in scheduling
  • Ability to block certain file types during file upload
  • Additional details for tasks and collaboration project

For a complete list and more details please take a look into the What's new document for SAP Project and Resource Management

 

 

Enhancements in Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

 

Allowing contingent workers (cost center procured) to record time on enterprise projects

Modern project teams are a dynamic blend of internal employees and external contingent workers. A significant process gap existed for contingent workers who were procured via a cost center, as they couldn't use the standard “My Timesheet” application to record time against enterprise projects. This made it difficult to get a complete and timely picture of all labor hours and costs. With the 2602 release, we have closed this gap. Now, these contingent workers can use the very same “My Timesheet” application as internal employees to record their time against the projects they are staffed on, creating a unified experience for the entire team.

This enhancement delivers a unified and simplified process where all project resources, regardless of their employment type, use a single application for time recording, which improves the user experience. You can now capture every hour worked against your project demands in one central place, providing a more accurate and timely view of total project costs and progress. Furthermore, the system automates the creation of the corresponding service entry sheet and goods receipt upon timesheet approval, significantly reducing administrative overhead and ensuring your suppliers are paid accurately and on time.

Figure 3: Project-based and cost center-based contingent workers can record time seamlessly in the “Manage My Timesheet” application, ensuring consistent tracking and better visibility across all engagement types.

 

Automatic removal of billing block for sales order billing plans

Milestone billing is a fantastic way to align payments with project progress, but it has often been hampered by a manual step. Once a milestone was achieved, someone had to go into the sales order and manually remove the billing block to make that item available for invoicing, a delay that directly impacts cash flow. We have now fully automated this process. Building on a feature from our last release, the system now automatically removes the billing block from the corresponding billing plan item in the related sales order the moment a project manager confirms the completion of that milestone in the project.

By completely automating this process, you eliminate the manual hand-off and inherent delays, allowing you to invoice your customers the very moment a milestone is contractually met. This directly accelerates your order-to-cash cycle and improves cash flow. This automation also removes a tedious and error-prone manual task, freeing up your project controllers and sales administrators to focus their expertise on more strategic, value-added activities. The risk of human error is entirely eliminated, leading to a smoother, more reliable, and more accurate billing process from end to end.

 

Figure 4: For sales order billing plan items which are created based on enterprise project or WBS element milestones, the billing block is automatically removed when the related milestone is completed.

 

Joule as project assistant (beta), planned to be available mid-March

Setting up a new project can be a complex and time-consuming task, often requiring project managers to navigate between three or four different applications to define the scope, staff resources, and release the project for time recording. We are incredibly excited to give you a preview of how we are solving this with the future of project management: the Joule Project Assistant. This is our generative AI copilot, and we are starting with a beta agent designed to radically simplify the creation of internal projects. Instead of clicking through multiple screens, a project manager can simply ask Joule in natural language, e.g. "Create a new pre-sales project for the 'Rising Star' initiative, starting next week and lasting for one month.". Joule can then propose a template, adjust dates, staff the project, and release it – all within a single, conversational session.

This AI-powered assistant promises dramatic efficiency gains, condensing a multi-application process into a single, swift conversation that saves significant time and effort for your project managers. The intuitive, conversational nature of Joule makes project creation accessible to everyone, drastically reducing the learning curve and empowering users to initiate projects quickly and correctly. By leveraging templates from successful past projects, the Joule agent also helps ensure that new projects are set up consistently and in compliance with your company's standards right from the start. We are currently running a beta program for this and encourage you to get involved! Register for the Customer Engagement Initiative via this landing page as of March 15, 2026.

 

Figure 5: The AI-powered solution assists users in rapidly setting up projects by leveraging similar past projects when the volume is high, and projects are repetitive in nature.



Other innovations in Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

We know how critical it is to have a clear, unified view of project financials. That's why we’ve introduced the company code currency into the Project Cost report. Now, you can see a consolidated view of all your key cost figures including planned costs, actuals, commitments, and even project stock costs – all in a single, consistent currency. This provides a much clearer picture of your project's overall financial health and variance.

There is one important prerequisite to keep in mind: for the report to display in the company code currency, all the projects and WBS elements you select for that report must share the same company code. This ensures data integrity and accurate reporting. For a more detailed guide on this feature, I encourage you to check out the documentation on the SAP Help Portal.

Second, we’ve Improved system usability by segregating the profitability segment from settlement rules for clearer allocation and analysis. What does this mean for you? In the past, assigning profitability might have required you to set up a settlement rule. Now, for projects with revenue, you can assign the profitability segment directly to a billing WBS element using the "Assign" function. This is a much more direct and intuitive workflow. It saves you steps, simplifies the allocation process, and makes your analysis clearer and more efficient. As with all our features, you can find comprehensive details on this enhancement in the SAP Help Portal.

Finally, and this is something I’m personally very excited about, we are going beyond system features to build a stronger community. We are officially introducing the new CIP community – a collaborative space designed for our customers, partners, and SAP experts to connect. The goal is to build a powerful network where we can all share ideas, discuss best practices, and co-innovate on the future of enterprise and collaborative project scenarios. This is your platform to influence the direction of our products and learn from your peers.

If you are interested in joining this community and helping shape the future of project management at SAP, please reach out to my colleagues, Anke Junker anke.junker@sap.com or Varsha Chetan Manu varsha.chetan.manu@sap.com, to get involved.


The SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release for EPPM is all about making your project management more connected, automated, and intelligent. From ensuring a single source of truth to simplifying daily tasks for every project role, these innovations are designed to deliver tangible business value and set you up for success.

Thank you for your time, and I look forward to seeing how you leverage these new capabilities.

 

 

📽️ Watch the replays of our SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Early Release Series!

From January 12-16, we hosted a series of 22 expert-led live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management as well as 21 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand – anywhere, anytime.

 

🔎Find all our assets

We at Cloud ERP and SCM Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: SAP Portugal ATCUD: Preparing for the 2026 SAF-T Tables Deprecation
entry.content:
The Evolution of Compliance

SAF-T (and similar frameworks) has evolved significantly from being a simple audit file into a complex legal requirement affecting local usage. In Portugal, the introduction of ATCUD fundamentally changed how document series and number ranges must be defined and validated, creating a ripple effect across many SAP customizations.

When ATCUD was first implemented, it enforced stricter rules regarding document series and numbering. To bridge the gap between older implementations and these new local requirements, SAP introduced specific tables and exception mechanisms as interim workarounds. While these measures helped customers adapt at the time, they created parallel sources of truth for document definitions, making governance, compliance, and testing significantly harder.

The Technical Shift: What is Changing?

After nearly three years of live ATCUD operations, SAP is moving to "tidy up" the system by deprecating three legacy tables used in the past to provide as workaround to derive the same information.

Planned for deprecation in 2026 are:

  • FIEU_MFI Map Document Type to Invoice Type (FI Invoice): A legacy table used to hold mappings or exceptions for FI documents tied to SAF-T/ATCUD rules, often containing localized mappings that bypassed standard numbering rules.
  • FIPTC_DOC_EXC Define Number Ranges for Internal Documents: A table used to store document exceptions and special handling for print, output, and validation workflows, frequently utilized for legacy processes or third-party add-ons.
  • FIEUD_SDGEN: Map Sales Category to Invoice Type: A table where you define sales document categories that are not available by default. The corresponding invoice type is then inserted in the XML file.

Once these tables are deprecated, the only official customization sources for defining documents will be SIPT_NUMBR_FI_V2 (for Financial Accounting) and SIPT_NUMBR_SD_V2 (for Sales and Distribution) ... and don’t forget the series validation framework (transaction code: GLO_PT_SVC)

NOTE: These tables will remain available; however, they will no longer be relevant for SAF‑T reporting from 2026 onward.

Why This Consolidation Matters The primary goal of this deprecation is to remove redundancy and force a single authoritative configuration for series and number ranges that aligns with legal ATCUD requirements. Consolidating document definition into the SIPT_NUMBR_* tables offer several benefits:

  • Consistency: It reduces the chance of two subsystems defining the same document differently.
  • Simplified Audits: It eliminates the complexity of checking multiple control points.
  • Governance: It removes the risk of "less-informed users" relying on legacy settings that cause inconsistencies.

Conclusion Start your discovery phase now by running an impact assessment for the legacy tables and mapping every dependency. Engaging your implementation partner early allows for proper planning and testing, ensuring the migration goes smoothly well before the 2026 deadline.

For more information, check SAP note 3688051 and SAFT collective note 1981139

Solution for Public Cloud to be available soon

Hope you enjoyed this information. Don't forget to leave your comments. 

Elsa

entry.title: Re: Ehanced limits for PO is not applicable for invoices
entry.content:
Dear @jerrysam,

Yes in Public Cloud you can control this. What you are seeing posting invoices far above the Enhanced Limit Overall Limit typically happens when the invoice tolerance check for limit items is not configured or the message is configured only as a warning

For Enhanced Limit PO items (item category E), SAP uses specific Logistics Invoice Verification (LIV) tolerance keys and message control:

  • Tolerance key LA = checks whether the invoice exceeds the overall limit of the limit/enhanced-limit item (message M8298)
  • Additionally, if you use performance periods and invoice directly against the PO (without SES/GR), tolerance key LD may be relevant (message M8297)

To make it an error (hard stop) at posting, you must do both:

  1. maintain the tolerance limit and
  2. set the message severity to Error

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002841906

Steps to do:

1. Maintain the tolerance limit for LA:

In CBC go to 101947 Set Tolerance Limits

Create/maintain an entry for your Company Code with tolerance key:

  • LA (PO limit amount exceeded)

Set the upper limits so that any exceed over the overall limit is rejected. This meaning, the system should not accept exceeding the overall limit at all

More details in SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003052672

2. Set message M8298 to Error not Warning

Search for 102091 Define Message Types for Area M8 and set:

  • Message: M8 298 ->Type = Error

 

This is the step that turns the tolerance violation into a hard posting error instead of a warning

3. Important process note (SES / GR indicator)

If your process is Lean Services with Service Entry Sheets:

  • When the PO item has Goods Receipt indicator set, SAP expects the SES to be the controlling document and some checks happen at SES time, not only at invoice time
  • If you allow invoices directly against the PO (no SES required) then the invoice tolerance setup above becomes even more critical

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002841906

4. Quick test

  1. Create an Enhanced Limit PO with Overall Limit = 5,000 EUR
  2. Create supplier invoice with reference to that PO for 6,000 EUR
  3. Expected result after the setup: Posting is blocked with an error

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: How to enable BC Set support for BC app
entry.content:
Introduction

In order to use the "import from transport" function in the BC Set editor, the data must be recorded in the context of a transport object (TOBJ) and the business configuration maintenance object (SMBC) must maintain the corresponding transport object attribute.

This blog explains the necessary steps to enable existing SMBC objects for the "import from transport" functionality. Newly generated SMBC objects are automatically enabled.

This blog is relevant for

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP BTP ABAP environment

Further reading:

  • Related blog posts
  • Learn how you can use ABAP technology to develop innovative applications and business solutions across SAP’s portfolio on SAP Learning Site.

Case 1: Transport object is already used in the BC app

As of release 2302, when you use the ADT wizard to generate a business configuration maintenance object (SMBC), a transport object (TOBJ) is generated by default and used in the behavior implementation. In this case you only need to maintain the new "Transport Object" attribute of the SMBC object.

You can do this manually in the ADT editor of the SMBC object or programmatically. First you need to find out the name of the transport object. In most cases the name is equal to the name of the SMBC object. You can open the behavior implementation class and check the first couple of rows to verify the name of the transport object ( depending on the release the object was created: CO_TRANSPORT_OBJECT or TDAT_NAME )

CLASS LHC_COMPANYCODEALL DEFINITION FINAL INHERITING FROM CL_ABAP_BEHAVIOR_HANDLER.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CONSTANTS:
      CO_ENTITY TYPE abp_entity_name VALUE `ZI_COMPANYCODE_S`,
      CO_TRANSPORT_OBJECT TYPE mbc_cp_api=>indiv_transaction_obj_name VALUE `ZCOMPANYCODE`,
      CO_AUTHORIZATION_ENTITY TYPE abp_entity_name VALUE `ZI_COMPANYCODE`.
CLASS LHC_RAP_TDAT_CTS DEFINITION FINAL.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS:
      GET
        RETURNING
          VALUE(RESULT) TYPE REF TO IF_MBC_CP_RAP_TDAT_CTS.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS LHC_RAP_TDAT_CTS IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD GET.
    result = mbc_cp_api=>rap_tdat_cts( tdat_name = 'ZTAB6'

You can maintain the attribute "Transport Object" in the "Service Configuration" section of the SMBC object in the ADT editor. Save and activate.

You can update this attribute also programmatically:

CLASS zset_tobj DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_oo_adt_classrun .
  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zset_tobj IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD if_oo_adt_classrun~main.
    DATA smbc_id TYPE TABLE OF if_mbc_cp_api_business_config=>ty_technical_id WITH EMPTY KEY.
    SELECT ABAPObject FROM I_CustABAPObjDirectoryEntry
      WHERE ABAPObjectType = 'SMBC' AND ABAPObject LIKE '<NAMESPACE>%'
      INTO TABLE @smbc_id .
    LOOP AT smbc_id ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<smbc_id>).
      out->write( |SMBC object: { <smbc_id> }| ).
      TRY.
          DATA(tobj) = mbc_cp_api=>business_configuration_api( <smbc_id> )->read( )-transport_object.
          IF tobj IS NOT INITIAL.
            out->write( |TOBJ already set: { tobj }| ).
          ELSE.
            mbc_cp_api=>business_configuration_api( <smbc_id> )->update_transport_object(
              transport_object = <smbc_id> "if the table list of the transport object does not match the table list of the behavior definition an exception is raised
              transport        = '<Workbench Request>' ). "transport=space for local objects
            out->write( |TOBJ set: { mbc_cp_api=>business_configuration_api( <smbc_id> )->read( )-transport_object }| ).
          ENDIF.
        CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(exc).
          out->write( |Error: { exc->get_text( ) }| ).
      ENDTRY.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

Use Case 2: The BC app does not use a transport object

Delete the existing BC app and create it again using the ADT wizard.

If you cannot do that, you can also use the ADT wizard to generate a new BC app for the table(s) with different object names. Move the generated transport object to the package of the old BC app and maintain the transport object attribute of the old SMBC object.
If necessary, adjust the generated TOBJ by changing the table piece list.
Adjust the old behavior implementation class by by replacing the existing method implementation with the equivalent method implementation of the new behavior implementation class. Adjust the constants to match the old object names.
You can now delete the newly generated objects.

entry.title: Re: Skills in SAP SuccessFactors: Field Guide for a Clean Build (TIH, JPB, CPM, OMP)
entry.content:
@Nadine2 

Hello Nadine,

Thanks for your kind words,

I would recommend to: 

1) Keep a clear “system of record” split

  • People Profile / EC (Background elements): education, work experience, etc. = HR master/background record.

  • Growth Portfolio (TIH): attributes used for matching, recommendations, development, opportunity marketplace, etc.

This prevents the “everything becomes a custom attribute” trap.

2) Use TIH standard types where possible
SAP’s TIH guidance/learning materials show Competency, Skill, and Language as standard attribute types, with the option to create more custom types. So if Language is part of your skills-led matching, it’s reasonable to maintain it in TIH.

3) Use JPB custom attribute mapping only for role expectations
Use the new capability for things that are genuinely role requirements / role context, for example:

  • certifications, tools/technologies, domain knowledge

  • working styles, preferences, motivations (your examples are spot-on)

  • any “must-have / nice-to-have” capability signals

Thanks!

Nagesh Polu.

entry.title: Composable Storefront local setup and OAuth Framework Update JDK21
entry.content:
Introduction

Since SAP Commerce Cloud Framework Update JDK21, OAuth flow is totally different and more secure. We're not using anymore password authentication directly on OAuth stack.  In replacement, OAuth PKCE Flow is now used: https://oauth.net/2/pkce/

You can run the playground example if you want to familiarize yourself with : https://www.oauth.com/playground/authorization-code-with-pkce.html

Local setup

Domain checking is more strict. And default localhost should be forgotten. In our example, it is based on Spartacus Sample data from B2C Electronics WebShop.

In your Operating System, you need to declare an explicit domain name

vim /etc/hosts
127.0.0.1 electronics-spa.local

In your Composable Storefront app, you need to review NodeJs start up command line to include your domain name

package.json
"start": "ng serve --host electronics-spa.local",

 OCC API EndPoints need to be updated too

spartacus-configuration.module.ts
baseUrl: 'https://electronics-spa.local:9002',

SAP Commerce CORS rules need to be updated to allow Composable Storefront

corsfilter.default.allowedOrigins=http://electronics-spa.local:4200
corsfilter.commercewebservices.allowedOrigins=http://electronics-spa.local:4200
corsfilter.permissionswebservices.allowedOrigins=http://electronics-spa.local:4200
corsfilter.personalizationwebservices.allowedOrigins=http://electronics-spa.local:4200
corsfilter.acceleratorservices.allowedOrigins=http://electronics-spa.local:4200

And finally, you can import this following Impex to setup OAuth client parameters

# Public OAuth Client Credential
INSERT_UPDATE OAuthClientDetails; clientId[unique=true];public;authorities ;scope ;authorizedGrantTypes;registeredRedirectUri;loginPageUri   
;mobile_android_public;true;ROLE_CLIENT;basic;authorization_code,refresh_token ;http://electronics-spa.local:4200 ;/login

As you can notice, there's no password setup for this client. Authentication flow is using authorization code and SAP Commerce as IdP and login page host.

Testing

http://electronics-spa.local:4200/electronics-spa/en/USD/

When you click on Sign in, you should be redirected to SAP Commerce where login page is hosted

https://electronics-spa.local:9002/authorizationserver/login

After password validation by SAP Commerce, temporary code is generated and send back to SAP Composable Storefront. Then, this code is sent to OAuth layer for validation. And finally, user is redirected to Home Page.

http://electronics-spa.local:4200/?code=BD4mlnvjBnnpkfPP2wqC4Q0evvODFYObjPH8uGzYo-k4QcXn8TFnTs

http://electronics-spa.local:4200/electronics-spa/en/USD/

 

Conclusion

This article should help you to setup your local project and to understand behind the hood how OAuth flow work. If you need more assistance, please don't hesitation to contact direct SAP Expert Service team : sapcx-expertservices@sap.com
